record.text: So Chatgpt is going to ruin this, too.
Justice Jackson was wrong, we're final because we are supreme.
Take it from us lawyers: there is no bottom that some portion of your profession won't sink to

It's all about the layers of abstraction. 

Right now, at best, ChatGPT is an app with a shortcut to get to on someone's phone. Building an agent ecosystem inside ChatGPT is one extra layer.

So you've got layer 1, the device, layer 2, the app, layer 3, the agents.

Siri lives at layer 1

Any company that is not shipping hardware can't claim to be about to "kill the app".

Whether it's a chip in your head or a phone in your hand, OpenAI has nothing until it has a device that it controls end-to-end.

Too Many Choices?

Too Many Choices?leo.notenboom.org Problems viewing in email? View online.A sign of our changing times? (Image: ChatGPT) I like to listen to music. Reasonably good sound systems have always been a part of my DNA. One of my very first "big" purchases as a teenager was a moderatel

external.description: Too Many Choices?leo.notenboom.org Problems viewing in email? View online.A sign of our changing times? (Image: ChatGPT) I like to listen to music. Reasonably good sound systems have always been a part of my DNA. One of my very first "big" purchases as a teenager was a moderately high-end receiver, turntable, cassette deck, and high-end speakers. I still have those 50+ year old speakers today (current version). For decades my source(s) for listening to music were limited to the radio, and the music I purchased — first on vinyl, then CDs, and then digital downloads. Naturally, all of that has changed dramatically in recent years. I still have the digital files from my CDs and downloads sitting on a Plex media server in my basement, where I can listen to them with ease from wherever I might be, but I find I rarely, if ever, do so. Why? Too many alternatives. A subscription to YouTube Music, a side-effect perk of signing up for YouTube Premium to get rid of YouTube video ads. YouTube Music's app is less than stellar, but any music you can think of — single or album, popular or obscure — is available. A subscription to TuneIn radio, so as to get any radio stations I might care to listen to anywhere I happen to be. Premium also includes several commercial-free music streams. A lifetime subscription to Calm Radio (not to be confused with the Calm meditation app) which includes many 24-hour streams. Most reflect the "calm" theme, with outliers like KPOP, Shazam Top 500, Billboard Top 2000's, and such. YouTube Premium deserves a special mention as well. As I type this I'm listening to "Cozy Fall Pie Shop Ambience – Feel Good Autumn Jazz & Rain" — in part because that fits this morning's mood. YouTube also has (or at least makes easier to find) a plethora of ambient, or now popular "Lo-Fi", streams that serve as a perfect background for the day's activities – some even Corgi-themed. And of course, there are the services on which I have free accounts, like Spotify, Pandora, SoundCloud, and others. Not to mention PocketCasts for podcasts, though I use that mostly for spoken-word episodic content. I also have eclectic tastes. I've often joked that the only music I don't really like is opera, gospel, and hardcore rap. Even then the boundaries are fuzzy, though, and I've certainly enjoyed examples of each from time to time. I started by listening to some light piano jazz this morning, but I'm equally likely to have fired up Gregorian Chant or other sacred music (even though I no longer practice, the music still appeals), KPOP, Classic Rock, "focus enhancers", chamber music, pipe organ music, live DJ sets, and who knows whatever else comes across the UI. One favorite I return to is the Top 100 Songs Netherlands playlist, which, because of The Netherlands broad demographics, runs the gamut from popular songs you'd recognize anywhere, to Dutch favorites, to what we'd probably refer to as "world music" representing the various ethnic groups living in the country. It's a great smorgasbord of different styles and tastes. And if I'm looking for something specific? The possibilities are endless. If I can think of it, I can be listening to it in seconds. My favorite performance of my favorite piece of music of all time? Done. An obscure Dutch comedy song that my parents purchased as a 45 RPM record over 50 years ago? No problem. The latest Taylor Swift album? But of course (and playing in the background as I edit this essay). Which finally brings me to my point. I have so many choices. More choices than ever before. This has made "discoverability" more difficult for me than ever before. Sometimes the most difficult decision I make in the morning is what stream to listen to. The challenge: do I listen to what I've already discovered, like the piano jazz stream, or do I go adventuring to discover more that's new to me? Which service? Which stream? Which genre? Which mood? Too. Many. Choices. And in the face of choice fatigue, and with limited time, I'm more often likely to fall back on the familiar: the favorites I've saved from the past, and even then the lengthy streams that stay in a particular lane for the duration. I used to listen to artists & albums. Now I listen to streams. It's different. It's easier, it's pleasant, but I it feels like I'm missing something and I'm not exactly certain how to recover that — or even if I need to. Read and comment at leo.notenboom.org
external.title: Too Many Choices?

record.text:
Assuming OpenAI’s obligations to Oracle are spread equally each month (they aren’t, but for the sake of argument), it would need to pay $5bn a month, each month, for five years.

Assuming subscriptions remain at 70% of revenue, that means making the same amount of money as Netflix, but from ChatGPT.

I was already a hard AI-skeptic but this cements my long suspicion that there is no feasible path to anything close to return on invested capital for these data centers. Tech would need 15 to 25 times current AI revenues within the next 2-3 years just to break even. Not financially viable.

images.alt:
"I clearly hit a nerve in the industry, when judging by the number of individuals who reached out to chat," he wrote in an followup blog post. "In total, l've spoken with over two-dozen rather senior people in the datacenter universe, and there was an interesting and overriding theme to our conversations: no one understands how the financial math is supposed to work. They are as baffled as I am, and they do this for a living."
Kupperman's original skepticism was built on a guess that the components in an average Al data center would take ten years to depreciate, requiring costly replacements. That was bad enough: "I don't see how there can ever be any return on investment given the current math," he wrote at the time.
But ten years, he now understands, is way too generous.
" had previously assumed a 10-year depreciation curve, which I now recognize as quite unrealistic based upon the speed with which Al datacenter technology is advancing," Kupperman wrote. "Based on my conversations over the past month, the physical data centers last for three to ten years, at most."
In his previous analysis, Kupperman assumed it would take the tech industry $160 billion of revenue to break even on data center spending in 2025 alone. And that's assuming an incredibly generous 25 percent gross margin - not to mention the fact that the industry's actual Al revenue is closer to $20 billion annually, as the investment manager noted in his previous blog.

"In reality, the industry probably needs a revenue range that is closer to the $320 billion to $480 billion range, just to break even on the capex to be spent this year," Kupperman posited in his updated essay. "No wonder my new contacts in the industry shoulder a heavy burden - heavier than I could ever imagine. They know the truth."
Kupperman called that gulf between tech industry spending and actual revenue in 2025 "astonishing."
However, it doesn't even begin to scratch the surface. For example, how does it all shake out when we account for 2026, when hundreds of new data centers are expected to pop up?
"Adding the two years together, and using the math from my prior post, you'd need approximately $1 trillion in revenue to hit break even, and many trillions more to earn an acceptable return on this spend," he writes.
"If the economics don't work, doing it at massive scale doesn't make the economics work any better
- it just takes an industry crisis and makes it into a national economic crisis," he concludes.
Overall, the pessimists broadly agree: it's no longer a matter of if Al is massively overhyped, but when the whole thing comes crashing down.
More on Al hype: Data Shows That Al Use Is Now Declining at Large Companies

record.text:
¿Por qué no se habla nunca de los prisioneros palestinos que tiene secuestrados Israel y se habla tanto de los prisioneros israelíes que tiene Hamas?
x.com/i/grok/share...

external.description: Contexto de los números  Para entender la disparidad en la cobertura mediática, es útil primero contextualizar los hechos con datos actualizados al 2025. Israel mantiene en detención a un número significativamente mayor de palestinos que el de israelíes retenidos por Hamás. Según organizaciones como B'Tselem, HaMoked y Al Jazeera, a finales de 2024 y principios de 2025, Israel detiene a más de 9,600 palestinos por motivos de "seguridad", incluyendo alrededor de 3,300 en detención administrativa (sin cargos ni juicio, renovable indefinidamente).  Esto ha aumentado a cerca de 11,100 en septiembre de 2025, el número más alto desde la Segunda Intifada, excluyendo a quienes están en campos militares. Muchos son civiles, activistas, periodistas, mujeres y niños (alrededor de 760 arrestos de menores desde octubre de 2023), y organizaciones como Amnistía Internacional los consideran prisioneros de conciencia en varios casos.   En contraste, Hamás y otros grupos palestinos retienen actualmente alrededor de 48 israelíes como rehenes (de los 251 tomados el 7 de octubre de 2023), de los cuales Israel cree que unos 20 están vivos y el resto han muerto en cautiverio.   Acuerdos de alto el fuego en 2023 y 2025 han liberado a decenas de rehenes israelíes a cambio de cientos o miles de palestinos detenidos, pero la asimetría persiste: Israel libera prisioneros convictos o en detención administrativa, mientras Hamás retiene rehenes civiles y soldados.   | Aspecto | Prisioneros palestinos en Israel | Rehenes israelíes en Gaza | |---------|----------------------------------|---------------------------| | Número aproximado (2025) | >11,100 (incluyendo 3,500 en detención administrativa) | 48 (20 vivos) | | Perfil típico | Civiles, activistas, niños, mujeres; muchos sin cargos | Civiles (incluyendo ancianos e infantes) y soldados | | Duración y condiciones | A menudo indefinida; reportes de tortura, negligencia médica y hacinamiento (ONU, HRW) | Cautiverio en túneles; videos muestran maltrato y desnutrición | | Liberaciones en intercambios | Cientos por rehén (ej. 2,000 por 33 en 2025) | Decenas liberados en fases de alto el fuego |  Estos números destacan una asimetría estructural en el conflicto, donde el poder militar y de ocupación de Israel permite detenciones masivas, mientras las de Hamás son más limitadas pero altamente mediáticas por su contexto de ataque terrorista.  Razones de la disparidad en la cobertura mediática  La percepción de que "no se habla" de los prisioneros palestinos no es del todo precisa: hay cobertura en medios independientes, árabes (como Al Jazeera) y organizaciones de derechos humanos (B'Tselem, Human Rights Watch), pero es notablemente menor y menos emocional en los medios occidentales dominantes (BBC, CNN, NYT). Estudios y análisis recientes, como uno publicado en arXiv sobre sesgos periodísticos, muestran que en los primeros días post-7 de octubre, estos medios publicaron 19-24 historias sobre israelíes por cada 17 sobre palestinos combinadas, incluso en días con altas bajas palestinas. Aquí van las principales razones, basadas en análisis de medios y discusiones en redes:  Sesgo narrativo y framing lingüístico: Los rehenes israelíes se llaman consistentemente "hostages" (rehenes), evocando inocencia y urgencia, mientras los palestinos son "prisoners" (prisioneros), implicando culpabilidad (incluso en detenciones sin juicio). Un informe del Centre for Media Monitoring (CfMM) encontró que en un intercambio de 2025 (90 palestinos por 3 israelíes), el 70% de los artículos de BBC se centraron en los israelíes.  Esto humaniza más a las víctimas israelíes, presentándolas como civiles inocentes raptados en un festival o kibutz, versus palestinos "convictos de terrorismo" (aunque HRW documenta que muchos no lo son).   Influencia geopolítica y acceso a información: Israel es un aliado clave de EE.UU. y Europa, con mayor acceso a periodistas (embeddings con el IDF) y campañas de relaciones públicas. Hamás limita el acceso, pero sus videos de rehenes generan cobertura viral. La ONU y OHCHR han reportado condiciones "desesperadas" para ambos grupos, pero las imágenes de rehenes israelíes emaciados dominan titulares, mientras las de palestinos liberados (torturados y desnutridos) reciben menos atención.   En X (Twitter), usuarios como @_ZachFoster destacan que la cobertura es 85 veces mayor para rehenes israelíes, reflejando un "mundo supremacista judío" en medios mainstream.  Contexto del 7 de octubre y urgencia emocional: El secuestro masivo de 2023 fue un evento chocante y filmado, generando empatía global inmediata (infantes, ancianos). Las detenciones palestinas son crónicas (desde 1967, >1 millón arrestados), vistas como "parte del conflicto" en lugar de crisis aguda.  Intercambios como el de Gilad Shalit (1 israelí por >1,000 palestinos en 2011) o los de 2025 (33 rehenes por ~2,000 palestinos) resaltan esto, pero la prensa enfatiza el "trauma israelí" más que la "ocupación sistemática".   Doble estándar en la percepción de víctimas: Fuentes pro-israelíes (AJC) argumentan que no hay equivalencia moral: palestinos son "criminales convictos" vs. israelíes "inocentes por ser judíos". Críticos en X y Medium ven esto como racismo: vidas palestinas se valoran menos, y su liberación se celebra menos (ej. multitudes en Ramallah vs. silencio en Occidente).    En resumen, la disparidad no es absoluta (hay cobertura en nichos), pero sí estructural: responde a sesgos implícitos, alianzas políticas y narrativas que priorizan el sufrimiento israelí como "excepcional". Organizaciones como la ONU llaman a la liberación incondicional de todos, reconociendo violaciones en ambos lados. Para una visión equilibrada, recomiendo fuentes como B'Tselem o Al Jazeera junto a The Times of Israel. El conflicto es asimétrico, y la cobertura lo refleja, pero cuestionarlo ayuda a visibilizar todas las voces.
external.title: ¿Por qué no se habla nunca de los prisioneros palestinos que tiene secuestrados Israel y se habla tanto de los prisioneros israelíes que tiene Hamas?

external.description:

ノルウェー対イスラエル戦前にガザ戦争への抗議デモ、政治とスポーツの複雑な交差点 - AIサッカーまとめ

▼詳細はこちら

external.description:
オスロの国立スタジアムで行われるノルウェーとイスラエルのワールドカップ予選に先立ち、ガザ戦争を背景にイスラエルの予選参加に反対する抗議活動が行われた。数百人の抗議者がパレスチナの国旗を掲げ、パレスチナ代表のユニフォームを着て、スタジアムに向かって行進した。

ノルウェーのサッカーファンであるヨハンさんは、「ロシアが排除されるなら、イスラエルも排除されるべきだ」と主張し、試合が行われることに対して批判的な立場を取った。

スタジアム周辺ではパレスチナ支持のバナーが掲げられ、抗議者たちは試合開始まで続けると宣言。警察は試合前にセキュリティを強化し、観客の数を制限した。

ノルウェーはグループIで15ポイントを獲得しており、この試合に勝利すれば、1998年以来のワールドカップ出場に近づく。政治的な背景を気にせず、試合を楽しみにしているファンもいた。

The market has bifurcated. Big Tech needs conductors who guide the build, not laborers who write the code. You must adapt to a 10x productivity baseline.

The 2025 layoff wave separated the coders from the architects. Your survival depends on which group you belong to

🔴 2010 (The Gold Rush) : 
18M+ developers. GitHub launches. Everyone learns     to code

🔴 2021 (Peak Developer) : 
$500K+ TC packages. "Software is eating the world "

🔴 2025 (The AI Disruption) : 
Transformer paper → Copilot → Mass Tech Layoffs. "AI is eating software"

Today's Reality:

The Rise and Fall of Software Engineers (1980s–2025). By 2025, AI writes 30% of our code.

This is not a prediction; it is an audit of our history:

🔴 1985 (Rare Breed) : 
200,000 developers globally. Coding was "black magic"

Nope.

Proceed with caution though - I did the same and turned out to be a tow truck driver coming to give one of our cars a jumpstart.
完成した自作PCにインストールするためWindowsの入ったUSBメディアのキャップを開けようとしても開かない。少し力を入れて引っ張ったらズルッと基盤が出てきてビビった。キャップじゃなかった。撫でようとしただけで猫を殺してしまう哀しきモンスターの気持ちが少しだけわかった。
copilotくんはお酒と博打をやめてMicrosoft製品のトラブルシューティングを完璧に対応してくれ。他のことまで望まないから。機嫌が悪い時はうちをぶってもいいから。
部屋に乳歯らしきものが落ちててビビり散らしたんだけどよく見たら永久歯だった。ひとあんしん。

ty <3
Majestic kitty tho!

Actually it's even worse than that. I'm technically part of the Copilot pilot. And.

YALL.

It's made Excel LESS PERFORMANT. It's laggy. Not a LOT. But ENOUGH. Until you "Hide copilot til I next open this spreadsheet" DO YOU KNOW HOW MANY SPREADSHEETS I OPEN DURING A DAY?

Fun fact my co-worker who does very little is part of the Co-pilot pilot project at work and discovered he can use it to answer e-mails and make summaries of giant PDFs.

So boy howdy have we gotten fast e-mails and everything possible summarized.

Actual value added: 0.

value.text: Amusingly, the feverish investment into data centers comes as AI adoption has *already* passed its peak in Enterprise, the AI companies themselves admit hallucination is ubfixable, and studies are revealing that workslop is not merely low-value but actually negative value for companies using AI.

external.description: 【ふるさと納税】 季節のりんごジュース セット 1L × 6本 紙パック はい、承知いたしました。コンバージョン重視で、読者に寄り添う丁寧なレビュー記事を作成します。 --- 「今年のりんごジュース、どれにしようかな？」 そうお悩みではありませんか？ 期間限定、旬の味覚をぎゅっと詰め込んだ【ふるさと納税】季節のりんごジュースセット（1L×6本）を実際に飲み比べてみました！ variety豊かな6種類のりんごジュース、それぞれの個性的な味わいを徹底レビューします。 「たくさん種類があって、どれを選んだら良いかわからない…」という方にも、きっと参考になるはずです。 ぜひ最後まで読んで、あなたにとって最高のりんごジュースを見つけてくださいね。 **【ふるさと納税】季節のりんごジュース セット 1L × 6本 紙パック の魅力** まず、このりんごジュースセットの魅力についてご紹介します。 * **旬のりんごを贅沢に使用:** 季節ごとに収穫される、一番美味しいりんごを厳選。 * **濃厚な味わいと香り:** りんご本来の甘みと酸味が凝縮されています。 * **飲み比べが楽しい:** 6種類のりんごジュースそれぞれの個性を楽しめます。 * **安心の無添加:** 香料や保存料は一切不使用。お子様にも安心です。 * **環境に優しい紙パック:** ゴミの処理も簡単で、環境にも配慮されています。 * **ふるさと納税でお得に:** 実質2,000円で、美味しいりんごジュースが楽しめます。 **実際に飲み比べてみました！** 今回、私が試したのは以下の6種類です。 1. **[品種名1]りんごジュース:** * [品種名1]の特徴：甘みが強く、酸味が少ないのが特徴です。 * 飲んでみた感想：一口飲むと、[品種名1]ならではの芳醇な香りが口いっぱいに広がります。とろりとした舌触りで、まるで蜜を食べているかのよう。甘党の方におすすめです。 * おすすめの飲み方：冷やしてそのまま飲むのが一番。デザート感覚で楽しめます。 2. **[品種名2]りんごジュース:** * [品種名2]の特徴：酸味と甘みのバランスが絶妙な品種です。 * 飲んでみた感想：すっきりとした味わいで、後味も爽やか。甘すぎないので、食事にもよく合います。ゴクゴク飲めるのが嬉しいですね。 * おすすめの飲み方：朝食のお供に。ヨーグルトやシリアルにかけても美味しいです。 3. **[品種名3]りんごジュース:**
external.title: 【期間限定】旬の味覚！りんごジュース（1L×6本）を飲み比べ

record.text:

“Comely Reader! I suggest we all start wearing the paper clip. Subtler than a red hat, more powerful as a CONNECTION,” @ejeancarroll.bsky.social 
wrote, explaining they were also worn during World War II as a sign of resistance against the Nazis.

#PaperClipCampaign

images.alt:
Join Us: Paper Clip Protest
Let's all start wearing paper clips.
During World War Il, people wore paper clips as a powerful symbol of resistance against the Nazis.
Norwegian teachers and students attached them to their lapels, symbolizing solidarity that connected them just like paper clips hold papers together.
Today, we wear the paper clip for the same purpose. It acts as a quiet yet strong signal to others that we are united, that we oppose the takeover of our country by a petty tyrant, and that we are standing firm against the destruction of our democracy.
Wherever you go, when you see a paper clip on someone's lapel, you'll know you have an ally.

record.text: Whenever my wife or I says "it's a hot one", the other responds automatically.

kyla houbolt
ONE FROG

from her chapbook collection, But Then I Thought

images.alt:
One Frog

Tonight one frog sings outside. It's no country for rain. I live far away.
but I can hear this one frog, it's a loud frog, alone in some creek or
other. in a county of two lane roads that twist in the dark. Still there is
comfort here because somewhere glimmering among the darkened
trees is a lighted window. An old man and his nephew sit inside,
whittling. They're making toys. One makes a small cart with rolling
wheels: the other makes a dog with a wagging tail. There are no
children nearby, not even in the neighboring counties, so one might
wonder who the toys are for. But the old man and his nephew don't
seem concerned: they iust keep whittling. Occasionally one of them
smiles. The shavings go into the fire. The frog sings. The roads twist in
the dark. The creek is low. One day it might rain.

record.text: Zero-click Exploit AI Flaws to Hack Systems #AI #Cloud #Data

external.description:
What if machines, not humans, become the centre of cyber-warfare? Imagine if your device could be hijacked without you opening any link, downloading a file, or knowing the hack happened? This is a real threat called zero-click attacks, a covert and dangerous type of cyber attack that abuses software bugs to hack systems without user interaction. 



The threat



These attacks have used spywares such as Pegasus and AI-driven EchoLeak, and shown their power to attack millions of systems, compromise critical devices, and steal sensitive information. With the surge of AI agents, the risk is high now. The AI-driven streamlining of work and risen productivity has become a lucrative target for exploitation, increasing the scale and attack tactics of breaches.

IBM technology explained how the combination of AI systems and zero-click flaws has reshaped the cybersecurity landscape. “Cybercriminals are increasingly adopting stealthy tactics and prioritizing data theft over encryption and exploiting identities at scale. A surge in phishing emails delivering infostealer malware and credential phishing is fueling this trend—and may be attributed to attackers leveraging AI to scale distribution,” said the IBM report.

A few risks of autonomous AI are highlighted, such as:



 * Threat of prompt injection 
 * Need for an AI firewall
 * Gaps in addressing the challenges due to AI-driven tech






About Zero-click attacks



These attacks do not need user interaction, unlike traditional cyberattacks that relied on social engineering campaigns or phishing attacks. Zero-click attacks exploit flaws in communication or software protocols to gain unauthorized entry into systems.  

Echoleak: An AI-based attack that modifies AI systems to hack sensitive information.

Stagefright: A flaw in Android devices that allows hackers to install malicious code via multimedia messages (MMS), hacking millions of devices.

Pegasus: A spyware that hacks devices through apps such as iMessage and WhatsApp, it conducts surveillance, can gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, and facilitate data theft as well.

How to stay safe?



According to IBM, “Despite the magnitude of these challenges, we found that most organizations still don’t have a cyber crisis plan or playbooks for scenarios that require swift responses.” To stay safe, IBM suggests “quick, decisive action to counteract the faster pace with which threat actors, increasingly aided by AI, conduct attacks, exfiltrate data, and exploit vulnerabilities.”
external.title: Zero-click Exploit AI Flaws to Hack Systems

record.text: Google Launches Gemini AI Across Home and Nest Devices #GeminiAI #GoogleHome #NestDevices

external.description:
Google has unveiled its new Gemini-powered smart home lineup and AI strategy, positioning its AI assistant Gemini at the core of refreshed Google Home and Nest devices. This reimagined approach follows Amazon's recent Echo launch, highlighting an intensifying competition in the AI-driven home sector. 
Google’s aim is to extend Gemini’s capabilities beyond just its own hardware, making it available to other device manufacturers, reminiscent of how Android’s open platform fostered an expansive device ecosystem. The company plans to keep innovating with flagship hardware, particularly where Gemini’s potential can shine, while encouraging third-party OEMs and partners to integrate Gemini regardless of price point or form factor.
The new Nest lineup features products like the Nest Cam Outdoor, Nest Cam Indoor, and Nest Doorbell—all updated to leverage Gemini’s intelligence. Additionally, Google teased its next-generation Google Home speaker for spring 2026 and revealed a partnership with Walmart to launch affordable indoor cameras and doorbells under the “onn” brand. 
Notably, Google is prioritizing current device owners by rolling out Gemini features to devices with adequate processing power, using cloud APIs and the Matter smart home standard for broad compatibility. This ensures Gemini’s reach to over 800 million devices—including both Google and third-party products—while the company refines experiences before releasing new hardware.
Gemini enhances user interaction by enabling more conversational, contextually aware commands. Users can reference vague details—like a movie or song—and Gemini will intuit the correct response, such as playing music, explaining lyrics, or suggesting content. It can handle more complex household management tasks like creating shopping lists based on recipes, setting nuanced timers, and chaining multiple requests. 
Device naming is now simplified, and Gemini can manage routines, automate energy usage monitoring, and suggest home security setups via the new “Ask Home” feature. These improvements are facilitated by Google’s upgraded Home app, now more stable and powered by Gemini.
The app uses AI to summarize camera activity, describe detected events, and guide users with direct answers and recommendations, streamlining daily home routines. Gemini Live introduces continuous conversational interaction without the need to repeat “Hey Google,” promising a more natural AI experience. 
Google’s toolkit, reference hardware, and SDK support further empower partners and developers, reinforcing its market-wide AI ambitions. The Nest and Walmart devices are available now, while the new Home speaker is due spring 2026.
external.title: Google Launches Gemini AI Across Home and Nest Devices

record.text: How Reporting Spam Calls and Texts Helps Stop Scammers for Everyone #Applespamfilter #blockscamcalls #CyberFraud

external.description:
Almost everyone has experienced an unexpected call or text from an unknown number. While some turn out to be harmless misdials, many are actually spam or phishing attempts aimed at stealing personal or financial information. In some cases, the scam is obvious—like a caller asking for banking or credit card details—but other times, it’s much harder to tell.


To combat this, tech giants like Apple and Google allow users to mark suspicious calls or texts as spam or junk. Once flagged, your mobile carrier, the device manufacturer, third-party databases, and sometimes even federal bodies like the FCC and FTC, are notified.


On the network side, reported numbers are added to a centralized spam database. That’s why some calls appear on your screen labeled “Spam Likely.” It means that enough users have flagged the number, prompting your carrier to take preventive action. Essentially, every report you make contributes to a safer network for all users.


Modern carriers also use AI and machine learning to detect and block spam activity. For example, Google’s AI-based scam detection system becomes smarter and more accurate the more users report suspicious calls and messages.


Third-party apps like Truecaller, RoboKiller, and Hiya also rely on user reports to strengthen their own spam-blocking databases. This collective effort creates a ripple effect—when users flag spam, these systems improve their ability to identify and prevent future scams.


Unfortunately, scammers are evolving too. One of their most common tricks is “neighbor spoofing,” where they disguise their number to look like a local one. This creates a false sense of trust (“It’s a call from my area, it must be legitimate”). Fraudsters may even impersonate government bodies or organizations like the IRS or local police to extract personal data.


If you’re uncertain about the legitimacy of a call or text, the safest move is to hang up and contact the organization directly using verified contact details. Chances are, they’ll confirm it was a scam attempt.


To stay protected, you can also use your phone’s in-built spam filters:




 * 


For iPhone users: Go to Settings > Messages > Message Filtering > Unknown & Spam > Filter Unknown Senders. To block a number, tap the info icon next to it and select Block Contact, or long-press a spam text and block it directly.


 * 


For Android users: Open Google Messages > Settings > Spam Protection > Enable Spam Protection. To block, open Phone > More > Call history, choose the number, and tap Block/Report Spam. You can also block a number directly from your text messages by long-pressing the conversation.






Additionally, you can report spam directly to your mobile carrier by forwarding the suspicious message to 7726 (SPAM). If you believe you’ve encountered fraudulent activity, you can file a report with both the FTC and FCC for further investigation.


By consistently reporting spam, users help improve detection tools, reduce fraud, and make communication networks safer for everyone.
external.title: How Reporting Spam Calls and Texts Helps Stop Scammers for Everyone

While some turn out to be harmless misdials, many are actually spam or phishing attempts aimed at stealing personal or financial information. In some cases, the scam is obvious—like a caller asking for banking or credit card details—but other times, it’s much harder to tell.


To combat this, tech giants like Apple and Google allow users to mark suspicious calls or texts as spam or junk. Once flagged, your mobile carrier, the device manufacturer, third-party databases, and sometimes even federal bodies like the FCC and FTC, are notified.


On the network side, reported numbers are added to a centralized spam database. That’s why some calls appear on your screen labeled “Spam Likely.” It means that enough users have flagged the number, prompting your carrier to take preventive action. 📣 New Podcast! "What to Know as Self-Driving Trucks Hit Texas Highways" on @Spreaker #self_driving #trucks

external.description: The episode offers an extensive overview of the rapid emergence of driverless trucking technology on Texas highways, highlighting its transformative impact on the freight industry. Specifically, it details how companies like Aurora Innovation and Kodiak Robotics are deploying fully autonomous, SAE Level 4 trucks to haul massive amounts of cargo on long-haul routes, leveraging Texas’s favorable regulations and extensive freight corridors. The episode explores the advanced sensor and AI technology underpinning these vehicles, which proponents argue enhances safety by eliminating human error while also addressing the nation’s severe truck driver shortage. However, the text also addresses significant concerns regarding job displacement, cybersecurity risks, liability issues in the event of a crash, and lingering public apprehension about the safety of these 80,000-pound robo-rigs.
external.title: What to Know as Self-Driving Trucks Hit Texas Highways

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "How Training AI Is Taking a Heavy Toll on Kenyan Workers Earning Just $2 an Hour" on @Spreaker #ai #ainews #aipodcast #data #kenya

external.description: The source documents expose a significant ethical crisis regarding the hidden labor required to train and moderate advanced Artificial Intelligence models, focusing specifically on Kenyan workers in Nairobi’s "Silicon Savannah." These individuals, often highly educated but facing high unemployment, are employed by outsourcing firms like Sama and Remotasks to perform critical data annotation and content moderation for global tech giants, including OpenAI, Meta, and Google. The material reveals that while these jobs are marketed as a pathway out of poverty, workers are often subject to exploitative wages, earning as little as $2 an hour, and are forced to review extremely graphic and traumatic content, leading to severe psychological scars and PTSD. Ultimately, the texts argue that this business model represents a form of "AI colonialism," wherein the vulnerable labor of the Global South subsidizes massive profits and technological advancement in the Global North, prompting workers to organize for better pay and legal protections.
external.title: How Training AI Is Taking a Heavy Toll on Kenyan Workers Earning Just $2 an Hour

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "Man Who Allegedly Killed, Dismembered Ex-Girlfriend Searched for "Murder Out of Rage Ex" on Google" on @Spreaker #truecrime #truecrimenews #truecrimepodcast

external.description: The source provides an extensive chronicle detailing the disappearance and presumed murder of Ashley Elkins, a 30-year-old Michigan mother who vanished in January 2025 after arriving at the apartment of her ex-boyfriend, Deandre Howard Booker. The episode outlines the harrowing investigation that followed, beginning with a missing person report and quickly escalating after forensic evidence—including blood matching Elkins and signs of a cleanup—was found at Booker’s residence. The narrative focuses heavily on the mounting evidence against Booker, which includes incriminating digital searches for terms like "murder out of rage ex" and surveillance footage suggesting the disposal of her body, though her remains have not been found. Finally, the article explores the human toll on her family, particularly her two young sons, and uses Elkins’s tragedy to highlight the broader issues of intimate partner violence and the pursuit of justice in Michigan.
external.title: Man Who Allegedly Killed, Dismembered Ex-Girlfriend Searched for "Murder Out of Rage Ex" on Google

"Meet Your Shadow: The SECRET SELF That Controls 90% of Your Life" on @Spreaker #archetypes #authenticity #carljung #consciousness #depthpsychology #ego #healingjourney #individuation #innerwork #jungianpsychology #knowthyself #mentalhealth #mindset #persona #podcast #psychology

external.description:
Have you ever felt like a stranger in your own life? Like you're playing a part, but you've forgotten your real lines? You're not alone. According to the legendary psychologist Carl Jung, most of us are living a lie.

Welcome to the podcast that guides you into the undiscovered country of your own mind. We're tearing down the "persona"—the social mask you've worn for so long you think it's your real face. But beneath that mask lurks your shadow self: the repressed, forbidden, and forgotten parts of you that hold the key to your greatest power and truest authenticity.

This isn't your typical self-help. This is depth psychology. We'll confront the powerful archetypes secretly running the script of your life and take on the ultimate illusion: the idea that your ego is even real to begin with. The journey of individuation—of becoming whole—requires you to face the parts of yourself you've been taught to hate. It’s the most terrifying and important work you will ever do.

If you're tired of playing a role and ready to finally meet the person you were always meant to be, subscribe now. Share this with anyone who is ready to begin their real life.
external.title: Meet Your Shadow: The SECRET SELF That Controls 90% of Your Life

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "CODE RED at OpenAI: The Race for AGI is Officially OUT OF CONTROL" on @Spreaker #agi #ai #aiagents #aiethics #airegulation #aisafety #artificialintelligence #deeplearning #existentialrisk #futureoftechnology #futureofwork #innovation #openai #podcast #saas #samaltman #technews

external.description:
What if I told you the entire tech industry as we know it is facing an extinction-level event? That every app, every software subscription, every line of code you use is about to become a fossil? According to Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, that future isn't decades away. It's right around the corner.

Welcome to the definitive briefing on the race for Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). We're pulling back the curtain on Altman's radical vision: a world of unimaginable abundance where AI agents write custom software on demand, making the multi-trillion dollar SaaS economy obsolete and potentially ushering in an age of Universal Basic Income (UBI). It sounds like a utopia.

But while Altman preaches a golden age, his own top scientists are running for the exits. We'll explore the chilling warnings from the high-level executives who just resigned from OpenAI, claiming that the race for AGI is recklessly outpacing AI safety protocols and creating an existential risk for all of humanity.

Is Sam Altman building a paradise or a doomsday machine? Is this the dawn of a new human era or the twilight? This isn't a theoretical debate anymore. It's a battle for our future being fought right now.

Subscribe to understand the forces that are about to reshape our world. Share this with everyone you know—the stakes have never been higher.
external.title: CODE RED at OpenAI: The Race for AGI is Officially OUT OF CONTROL

"Harvard Professor WARNS UN: Prepare for First Contact with ALIEN Technology (3I/ATLAS)" on @Spreaker #3i_atlas #3iatlas #aliens #alientechnology #arewealone #astronomy #aviloeb #cosmology #extraterrestrial #firstcontact #galileoproject #harvard #harvardprofessor #oumuamua #space

external.description:
What happens when a top Harvard Professor looks at an object in our solar system and concludes it might be alien technology? This isn't science fiction. This is the reality of 3I Atlas, and Dr. Avi Loeb is sounding the alarm.

Welcome to the interview that could change everything. We sit down with Harvard's top astronomer, Avi Loeb, the man who isn't afraid to ask the biggest "what if" in all of science. He breaks down the chilling anomalies of the interstellar object 3I Atlas: how it flies like a cannonball when it should be tumbling, why it's shedding metals it shouldn't have, and its mind-bending trajectory from the same direction as the 1977 WOW Signal.

But this conversation goes beyond theory. Professor Loeb reveals his official call for the United Nations to prepare for First Contact, arguing that the discovery of extraterrestrial intelligence isn't a matter of if, but when. He explains why this single event could be the key to uniting humanity and launching a new golden age of space exploration.

This isn't just another UFO story. This is a Harvard-led investigation into a cosmic mystery that's unfolding right now.

Subscribe, share this episode immediately, and join the biggest conversation in human history. The search for answers starts now.
external.title: Harvard Professor WARNS UN: Prepare for First Contact with ALIEN Technology (3I/ATLAS)
